content.protection: 2 bolts to chain anchors, a small piece down low for comfort.
content.location: Lower tier, left side of south face.

content.description: Find a gully 30 feet left of Big Cat Club. From the gully, turn left and find a splitter hand crack on a south-facing wall 20 feet from the gully. Jam over a low bulge (crux) at the start and then continue up a low-angled crack to the top. Walk off.
content.location: Upper tier, near Big Cat Climb.

content.description:
I saw this line at the Long Walk Rock area and couldn't find a route already listed that matched the description, despite it being quite an impressive line. I did see a comment mentioning something called Litterbox, so I'm using that until I receive more information.

I started beneath the right-trending crack and climbed up into it, following it to the lip. After that, it was easier slab terrain to the top where I walked off (I did it

sans

rope). I passed a single bolt on the upper slab, and the initial crack would easily take gear. This is a very fun and pretty line. If anyone has information on the name/grade/FA, please tell me, and I'll update accordingly.

L.A.T.E. = Long Approach, Tiny Enjoyment.

There's a gully 30ft left of Big Cat Club. Right at the lip of the gully, on the right side, is a thin crack/flake that heads up and left. Layback and jam this, staying left to get the most height out of the route instead of bailing out early on the right near the arete. Belay on top, scramble off the NE corner back into the gully.
Wide to OW crack splitting the middle of the south face on the lower tier.  Crux is getting off the ground and through the initial bulge.
content.protection:
Gear to 6", either walk off or traverse right to

Cat's Meow

anchors.
content.location: Obvious, wide crack splitting south face of lower tier.

content.description: Crack and steep face right of Cat's Meow.  Crux is getting off the ground and getting established on the face.
content.protection: One bolt and pin to chain anchors, a small piece down low for comfort.

content.description:
I wanted to get out hiking with my dog, and so I decided to check this place out, since I hadn't been there before. I wasn't intending on doing any climbing, but I once I got there, I decided to solo what seemed reasonable in the approach shoes I had on.

Anyway, begin about 15 feet left of "Big Cat Club," and climb straight up a shallow, left-facing dihedral. It's an ok climb in and of itself, but it is not worth the long approach.
content.protection: Thin gear. At the top, you could sling a horn or place a #0.5 Camalot and traverse right to chain anchors on "Big Cat Club" or scramble off the northeast corner of the formation.
content.location: It is 15' left of Big Cat Club on the west face.
